1068050 University of North Carolina at Charlotte; Michael Fiddy

The Center for Metamaterials (CfM) will focus on increasing the metamaterials research infrastructure in the U.S., and to educate and train students in the science and application of metamaterials. CUNY City College, Clarkson University (CU), and the University of North Carolina at Charlotte (UNCC) are collaborating to establish the proposed center, with CUNY as the lead institution.

Metamaterials are composite structures that exhibit extraordinary optical or acoustical properties including negative index of refraction, light harvesting, trapping, circulation, anomalous transmission of light, and many other properties not possible with naturally occurring materials or conventional optical components. Industrial applications for these new materials includes building perfect lenses, light harvesting for renewable energy devices and building new high performance sensors. This proposal seeks to develop an I/UCRC program that will perform industrially relevant metamaterials research leading to quick and cost-effective transition of metamaterials technology from US based university research laboratories to industry. The program involves three institutions with various strengths that can supplement theoretical understanding, device manufacturing, and characterization of a variety of metamaterial concepts. The three main technical foci of the CfM Center for Metamaterials that have attracted industry interest include: Theory and Anomalous Behavior, Materials and Structures Development, and Fabrication Process Development.

Broader Impacts include the enhancement of metamaterials R&D and technology transfer infrastructure, student training (including minority students at many of the minority serving colleges within CUNY) in an emerging high technology field, training of CfM member companies' workforce through the CfMs Education and Outreach Program. Additionally, long term economic impact is expected through high technology job creation and the formation of metamaterials spin-off companies, and increased revenue for US based high technology companies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Metamaterials are man-made materials having properties that go beyond those found in nature. These engineered materials are changing how sensing, imaging, antennas and energy harvesting can be achieved. The Center for Metamaterials (CfM) has been focused on collaboration with industry and government labs primarily on these four topics.  Considerable progress has been made to better understand and exploit new properties associated with such structured materials and outcomes from projects have advanced these areas.  In Phase I the University partners the University of North Carolina at Charlotte, the City University of New York and the Clarkson University provided complimentary capabilities that contributed to the industry advisory board (IAB) projects. Longer term fundamental research concerned with generic bulk metamaterial design has proved important while several shorter term projects directed towards specific applications exploiting metamaterials have reported out.  Our research has impacted a broad range of industries with development of optical and acoustic metamaterials in addition to the primary fields of sensing, imaging, antennas and energy harvesting. Metamaterials research and development has the potential to drive dramatic performance improvements in diverse areas such as renewable energy, communications, medical technology, avionics, consumer electronics, homeland security and defense. Hitherto unknown material properties can transform device and system design as well as power consumption and form-factor.  Our Center products already include new solutions to IR camera imaging sensitivity and sensing structures that can improve fiber optic data transmission speeds.  These breakthroughs can lead to the formation of metamaterials spin-off companies and an expansion of US based high technology companies. 

The new way of thinking about materials resulting from the global surge in metamaterials requires a workforce educated and trained with knowledge and experience.  The CfM is uniquely positioned to provide this training and education. Our university programs for IAB members and students (both graduate and undergraduate) now include workshops, courses and IAB-supported internships. CfM partnerships with IAB members provide important demos and presentations designed for our outreach efforts to high school and wider public audiences. Our center partnersvery cohesively with industry and government labs to work towards a set of metamaterial-driven goals which is focused on their societal and technological impact.  The CfM aims to become a national resource that brings industry coordination and critical mass to these emerging opportunities. The CfM has had an excellent knowledge transfer base over the Phase I period. Seven of CfM students have been hired by our member companies, and one more will be receiving an offer upon graduation.  Also there have been more than 16 internships for students, some for summer only and others year round.  In the past 5 years, the CfM has averaged more than 10 journal publications per year and nearly 20 conference proceedings/presentations per year, many of which are high impact factor journals.  There has been one book published and several book chapters.  During this period 30 CfM students have graduated; 26 of them after defending their thesis/dissertations (this number includes undergraduates). There have also been IP disclosures resulting in licensing interest from member companies.  This totals to more than 180 products throughout the lifetime of the Phase I grant with growth in all areas.
